s.text: A program was written in DELPHI to calculate the strength of a branch point.
The size of this window would be defined by the time taken for the protein complexes to bind as the nascent RNA emerges.
Every 5-nucleotide sequence within the window was evaluated as a potential branch point.
A relatively low score points to a suboptimal branch point or to a branch point situated outside the chosen window (-50, -10).
The 'standard' branch point sequence weight-table [ 4 ] was used to assign a score at every 5-nucleotide sequence within the window.

The mfold computer program version 3.0 http://bioinfo.math.rpi.edu/~mfold/rna/form1.cgiwas used to predict the RNA secondary structure and to calculate the folding free energy [ 26 27 ] . We have computed the minimum-free-energy structures from all the donor- and acceptor sites of the 60 exons of NF1 within a window of 100 bp.
We searched for branch point sequences in a window of -50, -10 with respect to the acceptor site.
The calculated scores demonstrate that deletions or insertions sometimes occur at strong cryptic splice sites (e.g.

In general, sequences that show a better match to the consensus sequences, indicated by a higher calculated score, are considered to be 'strong', as specificity of the splicing reaction is mediated in part by RNA-RNA interactions between these sequences and snRNA molecules.

On the other hand, comparison of the ground state of a mutant donor site, as was done for G1185+1U and G1185+1A in [ 19 ] , to the higher energy structure of the normal donor is superfluous to explain skipping.
Identification of novel NF1splice variants in normal cells

The mfold computer program version 3.0 http://bioinfo.math.rpi.edu/~mfold/rna/form1.cgiwas used to predict the RNA secondary structure and to calculate the folding free energy [ 26 27 ] . We have computed the minimum-free-energy structures from all the donor- and acceptor sites of the 60 exons of NF1 within a window of 100 bp.
